hero.title: Gabriel Gauthier
hero.subtitle: Programmer – Game and Software Development
hero.tagline: A detail-oriented programmer with a strong background in game design

about.title: Gabriel Gauthier
about.intro: Hi! I’m a programmer with a bachelor’s degree in game creation from UQAT and a certificate in applied computer science from UdeM. Curious and always eager to learn, I love coding, solving technical challenges, and bringing ideas to life through well-designed systems. I enjoy collaborating with passionate people, sharing knowledge, and helping projects move forward in a positive team environment. I’d love the opportunity to build something great with you!

involved.title: Dedicated
involved.text: When I take on a new project, I fully commit and see it through to the end.

feedback.title: Open to feedback
feedback.text: I’m at the beginning of my career and still have areas to improve. I appreciate constructive feedback that helps me grow.

curiosity.title: Eager to learn
curiosity.text: I love learning new things. If I have an opportunity to improve or develop new skills, I’m always in.

where.title: Where do I see myself?
where.text: My dream job would be in a motivated, organized, and fun team where everyone can share ideas and shine together. One day, I might like to become a technical lead.

what.title: What kind of projects?
what.text: I’ve worked on many projects, but my favorites are innovative games. I love adventure and puzzle games like It Takes Two, and I also enjoyed working on virtual reality projects.

games.title: Video games
games.text: I love video games for the emotions they create and the endless possibilities they offer. They’ve always pushed me to grow and inspired me to create memorable experiences.

nature.title: Nature
nature.text: Fascinated by wildlife and plants. I enjoy calm moments, exploration, and the peace nature provides.

anime.title: Japanese anime
anime.text: I fell in love with their culture and values, especially perseverance and self-improvement.

boltnpunch.title: Bolt'n'Punch
boltnpunch.description: Bolt’n’Punch is an action game developed with my graduating teammates at UQAT. We followed a full studio production pipeline, from initial concept to official release on Steam.

fioritura.title: Fioritura
fioritura.description: Fioritura was created by a team of 13 passionate students at UQAT. As the project integrator, I was responsible for connecting systems and ensuring technical consistency throughout development.

nineoclock.title: Nine O'Clock
nineoclock.description: Nine O’Clock is a team-based academic project developed by 10 students around an imposed theme. Over the course of a full semester, we designed and delivered a complete playable experience.

rexmontis.title: Rex Montis
rexmontis.description: This game was presented at Chaos Média 2021. It was developed in 8 weeks with the participation of my entire class, simulating a small game studio.

latency.title: Latency
latency.description: We created a fully playable and fun game during our prototyping and experimentation course in 2022, developed over one semester by a team of 6.

carnavalvr.title: Carnaval VR
carnavalvr.description: My first VR game, created during my internship at AleoVR. It was my first experience with VR development and studio production.

livraisonroyale.title: Livraison Royale
livraisonroyale.description: Game created during my first ever Game Jam, developed in 45 hours during the 2022 inter-college game jam competition.

megalophobia.title: Megalophobia
megalophobia.description: Game created during the 2022 Coding Block Game Jam in 3 days with a team of 5, based on the theme 'It’s following me'.

hero.title: Bolt'N'Punch
hero.description: Bolt’N’Punch is a first-person action game developed at UQAT by a team of 25 graduating students, published on Steam.

role.title: My role
role.text: I was assigned the role of programmer on the project, responsible for designing and developing new mechanics as well as improving existing ones. Each mechanic was designed in a modular way, with components that could easily be attached to objects and characters.

feature1.title: Hype system
feature1.text1: We wanted to encourage the use of special attacks rather than simple basic attack chaining.
feature1.text2: I was responsible for the complete implementation of the logic and balancing of the system.

feature2.title: Audio integration with Wwise
feature2.text: I also worked on integrating most of the game’s audio using Wwise. I learned how to properly place sounds in code and manage Wwise events, which helped me better understand how they function. This task, although complex, taught me a lot. I also had the opportunity to collaborate with the University of Montreal, which created our sounds — an experience I greatly appreciated.

feature3.title: Explosive barrel
feature3.text: I programmed a barrel that the player can grab and throw. On impact, it explodes in an area that detects all enemies, dealing damage and knockback. I designed the barrel as a modular component and added an aiming system with a trail that predicts the throw trajectory.

feature4.title: Animation blueprint
feature4.text: I worked on a core aspect of gameplay: the animation blueprint. My role was to integrate the character animations and create transitions between all states (walking, running, jumping, punches, charged attacks, etc.). This complex task taught me a lot, and the addition of aliases later made the system clearer and improved my future workflow.

feature5.title: Healing crates
feature5.text: I also designed a core gameplay element: healing crates. They are destructible and release energy bars that automatically move toward the player to heal them. I enjoyed developing them, and they play an important role in the game’s balance.

challenge.title: Technical challenges
challenge.text: I had to solve various bugs and limitations on my own, using my knowledge and mathematical calculations in code, such as cross products and percentages. This approach helped me strengthen my autonomy and better structure my solutions when facing complex problems.

hero.title: Fioritura
hero.description: Developed at UQAT by a team of 13 people using Unreal Engine 5, Fioritura is a puzzle game combining artistic exploration and original mechanics.

role.title: My role in the project
role.text: I had the pleasure of developing the isometric character controller, designing the architecture of the power-up system using event dispatchers, and implementing the flagship mechanic of the Éthéralys flower. I also actively participated in debugging and optimizing the project in preparation for the technical proof.

feature1.title: Character controller
feature1.text: As a programmer, I developed the isometric character controller, ensuring smooth movement without jump management. I also adjusted the camera behavior and iterated on the system until achieving a stable and functional controller.

feature2.title: Power-Up System
feature2.text: I then designed the power-up system based on three flowers offering distinct abilities. I implemented an architecture allowing smooth transitions between states and coherent interaction with the character and the environment. The system relied on an event dispatcher used to notify relevant objects when the active power changed.

feature3.title: Éthéralys Flower
feature3.text: I developed the Éthéralys flower mechanic, based on a spirit projection system with a character state change. This feature allowed the movement of a detached entity capable of ignoring certain collisions, interacting with targeted objects, and triggering teleportation via a receiver pot. I managed the synchronization between the body and the spirit, the handling of specific collisions, and the associated state transitions.

challenge.title: Technical challenges
challenge.text: We had one month to produce a technical proof demonstrating the game’s potential for publication on Steam. Despite the pressure caused by competition between projects, our team delivered a solid demonstration thanks to effective communication and good organization.
